events.long_description:
Explore Healing For Self - Monthly Event
Tania loves creating & holding sacred space for people & in this monthly event she will be creating a space where you can focus on your own healing journey in a group environment. In each session you will be guided through clearing, releasing, healing & remembering processes to help & assist you. We will explore different tools, processes & modalities each time to experience the highest possible energetic shift that is possible at that time.

Each month will have a different focus & flavour with the intention of working on yourself in a safe held space.
Over the next 4 sessions we will explore:

The 12 Chakra system, tools to use to help clear & heal the chakras and then enjoy a beautiful energy healing with the Archangels that are connected to each of the chakras.

Angelic Reiki - Receive an Angelic Cleansing, releasing old karmic connections with Archangel Michael, followed by a group healing with the angels wanting to connect with you.

Full Sensory Perception tools through Pleiadian Lightwork - an explanation on how the tools may feel & work & being in those energies & frequencies to receive the clearing & healing that is possible.

Access Bars - How ‘running the bars’ can help, some key points to use for stress or healing, running clearing statements to release old beliefs & patterns. What else is possible & how does it get any better than this.

There is a lot to explore & embrace and there may be additional processes brought in as Tania is guided or as time allows.

First Tuesday of the month 10am-12pm $30


Tania is a gifted intuitive and holistic practitioner, known for her grounded presence and loving guidance. She is an Angelic Reiki Master Teacher, Pleiadian Lightwork Practitioner & Teacher, conscious channeler, and Access Bars Practitioner. With a rich background in intuitive and energy work, she brings a nurturing and empowering energy to both group workshops and one-on-one sessions.

Bookings are essential. Email Tania:

For more details Text/Phone Tania : 021 030 6507

events.long_description:
All your favourite Christmas traditions play out across four Saturdays in November and December. The Wellington festive season has a suitably summer flavour with a host of fun activities brought to you by Wellington City Council. 
Christmas in the Quarters kicks off with Christmas crafts in Midland Park on Saturday, 22 November. There are five craft activities to enjoy, plus face painting. Kids can also post a letter in Santa’s letterbox. On Saturday, 29 November, the whole family can enjoy Christmas music and performances. There will be choirs, hip-hop dance, ukulele playing, and more. Chill out and absorb the sounds and sights of Christmas.

events.id: Waiora Te Ūkaipō — The Homeland-The Opera House, Wellington, New Zealand-Wellington NZ
events.name: Waiora Te Ūkaipō — The Homeland
events.venue: The Opera House, Wellington, New Zealand
events.long_description:
The impact of colonisation and urban drift are themes in a theatrical reboot at the next Aotearoa New Zealand Festival of the Arts. ‘Waiora Te Ūkaipō — The Homeland’ was originally commissioned by the festival in 1992. Its return 34 years later at the 2026 festival is highly anticipated. It has become a landmark piece of New Zealand theatre — exploring the tension between past and future. Set in the summer of 1965, the play follows Hone, who brings his family from New Zealand’s East Cape to the South Island in search of a better life. As they gather for a beachside birthday hāngī with their Pākehā guests, buried secrets and cultural tensions rise to the surface. Far from their  tīpuna , the family must navigate questions of identity, belonging, and survival. 
Waiora Te Ūkaipō was conceived, written and directed by Hone Kouka (Ngāti Porou, Ngāti Raukawa, Ngāti Kahungunu). The multi-award-winning writer/director has penned 13 plays. Many have been staged in Aotearoa and further afield in Canada, South Africa, New Caledonia, and the UK. Waiora Te Ūkaipō is presented in partnership with the Aotearoa New Zealand Festival of the Arts, Te Ahurei Toi o Tāmaki Auckland Arts Festival, Auckland Theatre Company and Tawata Productions.

events.id: Heathers the Musical-The Opera House, Wellington, New Zealand-Wellington NZ
events.name: Heathers the Musical
events.venue: The Opera House, Wellington, New Zealand
events.long_description:
It’s Westerberg High, where popularity is a matter of life and death. Welcome to ‘Heathers the Musical”. Based on a movie with the same name, the show is a coming-of-age story dealing with love, heartache, defying expectations, and being true to yourself. It originally premiered in Los Angeles in 2013. Since then, the musical has had record-breaking seasons across the globe. It now makes its professional New Zealand debut in 2026, and Wellington is in line to join the school assembly. Described as a high-octane, black comedy rock musical, Heathers is packed with a mix of ballads and showstoppers. The catchy tunes are written by Kevin Murphy (Desperate Housewives) and Laurence O’Keefe (Legally Blonde: The Musical). 
The 1989 film starred Winona Ryder and Christian Slater. It quickly achieved cult status among audiences. Both the movie and musical follow high school student Veronica Sawyer. Veronica is just another nobody until she’s unexpectedly taken under the wings of the beautiful and cruel Heathers. When mysterious teen rebel J.D. arrives, Veronica learns that it might kill to be a nobody, but it's murder being a somebody. 
This special production will feature a stellar Australasian cast. So grab your scrunchies, break out the Corn Nuts and wait for the bell to ring.

events.name: Beehive to Business with Hon. Todd McClay
events.venue: Wellington Chamber Of Commerce,NTT Tower, Level 13, Wellington, New Zealand
events.long_description:
Beehive to Business with Hon. Todd McClay
Wellington Chamber of Commerce & Allen + Clarke present our Beehive to Business with Hon. Todd McClay

About this Event

Join us on Tuesday 2nd December for a very special, final Beehive to Business event of the year, with Hon Todd McClay, Minister of Agriculture, Forestry, Trade & Investment and Associate Minister of Foreign Affairs.

In a year full of global geopolitical shocks, tariffs and increasing complexity for exporters – there is no Minister better positioned to deliver the insights and direction your business needs to know than Minister McClay.

Minister McClay is at the forefront of some of the most pressing issues for New Zealand’s economic position, be it new trade deals, the pressure facing our exporters or increasing Foreign Direct Investment through new agency InvestNZ.

If your business is chasing exports, or new capital from overseas – this final Beehive to Business is not one to be missed.

This event is part of an ongoing series made possible by our partnership with premier consulting firm Allen + Clarke. Proudly based in Wellington, Allen + Clarke is equally at home advising the Beehive or business alike.

Agenda:
7:15am- Standing breakfast, networking
7:45am- Address
8:10am- Q&A
8:30am- Event concludes

Can't make it? to register for the free livestream. Sign up and watch at a time convenient to you.

events.long_description:
It’s time for the Sustainable Business Network Wellington community to get together for our final coffee catch-up of 2025! 
This is an SBN investor-only event.
Join us to celebrate the start of summer, share your sustainability stories from 2025, and look ahead to 2026. 
You’ll have the chance to shout-out about what’s been happening in your organisation, we’ll provide an update on the latest at SBN. That will include reflections from the Next Fest and Sustainable Business Awards. 
As always, this will be a great opportunity to meet other organisations in the network and form new connections in a welcoming and informal setting.
Our December event will be hosted by RNZ.
Not a SBN Impact Investor (member) and want to know about joining the network? Please email us at investor@sustainable.org.nz.

events.id: Messengers-National Library of New Zealand, 70 Molesworth Street, Thorndon, Wellington-Event Finder
events.name: Messengers
events.venue: National Library of New Zealand, 70 Molesworth Street, Thorndon, Wellington
events.long_description:
‘Animals first entered the imagination as messengers and promises,’ John Berger.
Messengers explores the enduring gaze shared between humans and other animals. The exhibition title is inspired by a line from John Berger’s seminal 1977 essay ‘Why Look at Animals?’ Berger argued that the relationship between humans and animals – ‘our unspeaking companionship’ – has been transformed by capitalism.
Messengers brings together historical and contemporary ways of looking at animals in photography and art. It features archival photographs from the National Library and Alexander Turnbull Collections, first taken by newspaper photographers in the mid twentieth century. The images capture everything from the polar bears once housed in Wellington Zoo, to an elderly gentleman standing amongst the life size concrete animal sculptures in his garden. These images are at once tender and loving, sentimental and silly, kind and indifferent.
Messengers places these archival photographs in proximity and conversation with contemporary sculpture and moving image works by four Aotearoa-based artists: Denise Batchelor, Brit Bunkley, Jane Dodd and John Ward Knox. From eerie AI and computer-generated animals to the hypnotic stare of a real live Ruru; from carved wooden godwits you can hold in your hand to ‘hominoid’ brooches, each artist’s work speaks to the ‘unspeaking companionship’ between humanity and other animals.
IMAGE Brit Bunkley, still from Transit, single channel video, 2025

events.long_description:
❤ Reiki has had an extremely powerful positive influence on my life, and on the lives of my clients and students, helping us all to heal and change mindset, physical and emotional conditions, and to see life in a new light.

Reiki helped with my recovery from Chronic Fatigue syndrome and Mental stress ❤ I will share this with you in this course and help you open your life to the positive transformation that Reiki can bring.

I am a Usui Reiki Master and Teacher with 27 years experience working consciously with energy and a growing number of happy students. I offer an accessible, supportive training experience which enables you to easily benefit from the natural healing experience.

This TWO DAY course offers 12 hours of in person training including attunement, a full manual, certificate of completion and ongoing support. Maximum of 7 participants to enable close support and interaction.

The Reiki Level 1 Course focuses on energy and how we use it, it involves being attuned to the Reiki energies and using them for self-practice. Reiki is a great tool if you want to feel centered in your life, it helps to balance and align our energy bodies, and can cause positive changes in many areas of our lives.

When you receive your Reiki First Degree attunement you become a channel and are able to bring through healing energies ongoingly for yourself and friends and family.
Reiki can be used to help heal a wide number of conditions and to initiate and support positive life changes. Further details on enquiry.

Dates are specially chosen to be auspicious for firstly bringing energy to a new focus and purpose and the second date holds energies conducive to alignment.

SUNDAY 30th November and SUNDAY 7th December, 10am-5pm

The week gap in between the two training days allows you to receive support as you experience the 'cleanse' and integration period after the Reiki attunement - also offered is a Zoom follow up group session three weeks after the attunement date (time TBC)

Investment: $511 for full TWO day course, training, all support materials including manual, certificate, refreshments and ongoing support. Please bring food to contribute to lunch.

events.id: Botanical Insights talk - Ancient plants-Treehouse Visitor Centre, 101 Glenmore St, Wellington-Event Finder
events.name: Botanical Insights talk - Ancient plants
events.venue: Treehouse Visitor Centre, 101 Glenmore St, Wellington
events.long_description:
This talk, which partners a major pictorial display at the Tree House, starts with a look at landscapes preceding the rise of trees. It then focuses on the Silurian, Devonian and Carboniferous geological periods, characterised by the appearance of the likes of scale trees, seed ferns and calamites.….and the swamp forests that gave rise to the production of coal. Then it advances to the Permian period, including Gondwana prior to its eventual breakup, and the beautiful, strange, gymnosperm Glossopteris that was widespread in the ancient southern continents, embracing what is now New Zealand/Aotearoa. Finally, it progresses to the world of ‘living fossils’ such as ginkgo and the even more primitive horsetails. Attention will be drawn to some of the animals that populated this ancient world.

Located in the Treehouse Seminar Room, Wellington Botanic Garden ki Paekākā.
Free of charge. You’re welcome to bring along your own ‘brown bag’ lunch to enjoy during the talk.

The speaker is Reg Harris, a volunteer guide [botany] at Wellington Botanic Garden.
Reg delivers botany lectures for diverse audiences, delving into plant interactions, adaptive radiation, tropisms, and more. As a dedicated volunteer guide at Wellington Botanic Garden (WBG), he pioneered collaborations between WBG and Victoria University, organising annual field labs for biology students.

events.id: Electra Business After Five - 2 December 2025-10 Bath Street, Levin 5510, New Zealand-Humanitix
events.name: Electra Business After Five - 2 December 2025
events.venue: 10 Bath Street, Levin 5510, New Zealand
events.long_description:
December Electra BA5 
Electra BA5 Brad Olsen
The speaker is a familiar face, Brad Olsen, who is the Chief Executive and principal economist at Infometrics,  a nationally recognised economic intelligence and forecasting services.
We look forward to welcoming him back to Horowhenua for his latest economic update for the district and his insights into how the economy is doing as we head into 2026.

As an economist, Brad is passionate about using data and insights to drive solutions and outcomes that will benefit people, by understanding what is happening locally, and where there are emerging opportunities. He also brings this passion to his community, where creating meaningful change for people is the goal to strive towards. Brads particular skills lie in economics, community engagement, and governance, “the numbers, the people, and the boardroom. All three of these combine to allow me to help shape strategic directions which make a fundamental difference to people’s lives".
Electra Business After Five
Tuesday 2nd December 2025  
5.30-7pm $10+bf
Te Takeretanga o Kura-hau-pō, Levin

events.id: Fifty Years of New Zealand International Review-55 Lambton Quay, Pipitea, Wellington 6011, New Zealand-Humanitix
events.name: Fifty Years of New Zealand International Review
events.venue: 55 Lambton Quay, Pipitea, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
events.long_description:
This event commemorates 50 years of publication of New Zealand International Review, the NZIIA flagship publication for fostering discussion and understanding of international affairs as they relate to New Zealand. It also acknowledges the immense contribution of Ian McGibbon, who steps down as the Editor of New Zealand International Review after 44 years.
Join us to hear reflections from Ian on his four-plus decades in the role, a presentation by previous editor and historian Malcolm McKinnon on the evolution of New Zealand’s relations with the outside world and other speakers to be confirmed.
The event is followed by a food and drink reception.
Entry is on a 'pay what you like' basis to help cover the costs of the reception.

events.id: 8 week Pre Xmas Beginners Yoga Course-Yoga in Daily Life Centre, 23 Jessie St, Te Aro, Wellington-Event Finder
events.name: 8 week Pre Xmas Beginners Yoga Course
events.venue: Yoga in Daily Life Centre, 23 Jessie St, Te Aro, Wellington
events.long_description:
The Beginners Course teaches the “Sarva Hitta Asanas” from Level 1 - postures that are good for everyone. The Course covers all the foundations you need for an ongoing yoga practice as well as plenty of time for guided relaxation. Loosening your body, the joints, and your mind, the exercises are designed for the complete balance and awakening of energy in body, mind and soul. Experience yoga postures, breath techniques, meditation and relaxation, along with knowledge about basic yoga philosophy and a healthy lifestyle. A wonderful course for new beginners and those looking to deepen their practical experience of yoga.Some of the many benefits of yoga include: improvement in posture and breathing, increased strength and flexibility, a greater ability to cope with stress, and a feeling of peace and calm.
This course called "part 1" will cover the second half of Level 1 from the System of Yoga in Daily Life.

events.name: Brazilian Zouk Dance Classes - Beginners Block D
events.venue: 60 Dixon St, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
events.long_description:
Connect with other like minded people that have a love of dance.
Brazilian Zouk was developed in Rio de Janeiro in the mid 90s, and is now becoming more and more popular
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DfhRHnEAbak
Please note that there will be no class on 18th November, but we may run a practica
..............
This is stunning to watch and even more fun to dance! It is based on the original Lambada dance but adapted to more modern music with a slow-quick-quick beat. It can be danced to a wide variety of music including R&B, Rock and Pop.
In this block of 5 classes you will discover the fundamental techniques, movements and sequences of Brazilian Zouk to get you up and running on the dance floor.
This includes:
Week 1: Passo basico
Week 2: Lateral
Week 3: Soltinho
Week 4: Body Roll, and Snake
Week 5: Combination
They are designed so you can start this block as a complete newbie, or you can continue on as an existing student from the last block.
There are 4 blocks of classes (A, B, C, D) in the complete Fundamentals course. Once these are done, you can progress to the Improvers classes.
Prices and payment:
- Prepaid 5 week term cost is $90 waged or $75 for unwaged/students.
- Ad hoc cost is $20 waged or $18 unwaged/students
Online payments can be made to Adam Polaczuk
Acct: 03-0531-0559348-25
Details: Your name and ZoukFunD

events.long_description:
Tuesday Wellbeing Seminars

A FasterEFT-based workshop to clear old emotional blocks + activate your next level

Manifestation isn’t about forcing, chasing, affirming harder, or trying to “think positive”.

It’s about clearing the emotional data from the past that gets projected forward.

In this 70-minute transformative workshop, you will:

* Identify the hidden belief structures blocking your manifestation

* Release old emotional references using FasterEFT tapping

* Step into the identity of the version of you who already HAS the outcome

* Activate new nervous-system-based possibilities

* Lock in your new trajectory for the future

When the internal record shifts — reality reorganises instantly.

Join us for a powerful evening of nervous system re-coding, clarity, identity upgrade… and RESULTS

Meet Krishnaloka, your host
Krishnaloka is driven to help others overcome their issues within their mind and pyschology. As a mind technician trained in eutaptics (Faster EFT), she employs the fastest and most powerful method to create lasting change by addressing the root causes of issues rather than just the symptoms. Her warm and caring nature makes every interaction with her both comforting and transformative.

6.15pm Tuesday 2nd December

End the session on a high note with a delicious plant-based dinner, dessert, and good conversation.

events.id: Robin Hood - The Pantomime-1A Taranaki St, Wellington Central, Wellington 6011, New Zealand-Facebook
events.name: Robin Hood - The Pantomime
events.venue: 1A Taranaki St, Wellington Central, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
events.long_description:
Adventures of the original working-class hero and man in tights!
Robin Hood steals from the rich and gives to the poor in an oldie timey place where people are struggling and homeless, and the landed gentry hoard the money all for themselves – Wellington 2025.
Robin must stop the Evil Sheriff from running roughshod over the citizens! But this quest is far from easy… there is archery, swordfights, and a lot of dance numbers to get through. Our hero is grateful for help from spies on the inside: Maid Marion and her bolshie handmaiden (Pantomime Dame Jthan Morgan).
Come one and come all to see the slings and arrows of outrageous panto!

events.venue: Te Kupenga o Rongomai: Maidstone Sports Hub, 11 Railway Avenue, Upper Hutt, Upper Hutt
events.long_description:
13 - 15 (or 12 and attending year 9 at college next year)? Do you Dare to take the Cadet Forces Challenge? Come to our information evening, find out and register for a parade night visit to our HQ on Trentham Camp.

We are part of the New Zealand Cadet Forces (NZCF), a youth organisation like no other. Designed for teens ready to take on something exciting, real, and unforgettable. Whether you're keen to take to the skies, explore the outdoors, or get out on the range, there's a place for you in the Air Cadets.

Led by passionate volunteers and supported by the New Zealand Defence Force, the NZCF gives you the chance to develop leadership, confidence, and lifelong friendships through epic camps, unique training, and hands-on experiences that go way beyond the classroom.

This isn’t just a club. This is Cadets. Dare to take the challenge!

events.id: Brazilian Zouk - Head Movements - Rotisserie-60 Dixon St, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand-Facebook
events.name: Brazilian Zouk - Head Movements - Rotisserie
events.venue: 60 Dixon St, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
events.long_description:
Come and join us for Improvers Zouk Block F (5 weeks).
Please note that there will be no class on 18th November, but we may run a practica
We have some great new content for you this year and will be building on foundational movements.
The complete Improvers course consists of 6 different Blocks (A-F).
Each block focuses on a different aspect and technique of Brazilian Zouk and so they can be completed independently of each other.
Our recommendation is to complete all 6 Blocks before progressing onto the Brazilian Zouk Deep Dive classes.
In Improvers Block E you will get an Introduction to Head movements - Rotisserie, as well as some exercises on Creativity.
===Prices and payment:
- Prepaid 5 week Block cost is $90 waged or $75 for unwaged/students
- Ad hoc cost per class is $20 waged or $18 unwaged/students
Online payments can be made to Adam Polaczuk
Acct: 03-0531-0559348-25
Details: Your name and ZoukImpF
===Location:
Classes are in Footnote dance studio, 60 Dixon Street
===Housekeeping:
- You should have completed the 4 beginner Class blocks before joining Improvers classes
- Drop in or new students, please get in contact before the start of class to let us know you are interested so we can assess your level and organise a private class if necessary to catch you up. If you just show up on the night, you are welcome to watch the class but will not be able to join in (this is to respect the learning of our regular students as the classes are progressive)

events.id: Every Kind Of Weather-Circa Theatre, 1 Taranaki St, Wellington-Event Finder
events.name: Every Kind Of Weather
events.venue: Circa Theatre, 1 Taranaki St, Wellington
events.long_description:
A theatrical double-shot from an iconic playwright and one of our greatest actors.

Bruce Mason is perhaps the most significant playwright in Aotearoa New Zealand’s theatrical history. Writing with courage and insight, he was a lover of language and a champion of the underdog.

Between 1959 and 1978, Bruce toured the country, telling uniquely Kiwi stories about emerging identity, cultural cringe and social difference. From church halls to country shearing sheds to the Edinburgh Festival, Bruce would play anywhere, in any circumstance, to any audience.

To celebrate his extraordinary legacy, Brilliant Adventures and Circa Theatre are collaborating to make two of his greatest solo works resound for a new age.

Two plays: timeless, universal, distinct. Following their critically acclaimed, sold out run of THINGS I KNOW TO BE TRUE, actor Stephen Lovatt and director Shane Bosher return to Circa for a not-to-be missed theatrical encounter with a master craftsman.

THE END OF THE GOLDEN WEATHER
“I invite you to join me, in a voyage into the past, to that territory of the heart we call childhood.”

Bruce Mason’s quintessential Kiwi classic chronicles the friendship between a 12-year-old boy and Firpo, a social outcast who dreams of winning an Olympic medal.

Through the boy’s eyes we see the wonder of life on a perfect beach, in a perfect 1930s New Zealand, during a perfect summer. It’s a world of magic and transformation, where anything can happen and miracles seem possible.

When the boy sets out to help Firpo make his athletic dream a reality, ignoring his father’s rebukes and community ridicule, a battle rages between the eternal optimism of childhood and the harsh pragmatism of adulthood.

Gliding effortlessly between flights of poetic fancy and blunt everyday speech, THE END OF THE GOLDEN WEATHER is New Zealand storytelling at its very best.

NOT CHRISTMAS, BUT GUY FAWKES
An adolescent boy tries to find his place in an adult-dominated world. A young man retraces an intensely felt boyhood experience of bullying. A playwright in his last days reconciles the value of an artistic life and challenges the idea of New Zealand identity.

Comic disasters and confronting your own hubris. NOT CHRISTMAS, BUT GUY FAWKES is a richly autobiographical search for self-expression. Profound and true, it is a set of variations about over-reaching, cheekily confronting our very own Tall Poppy Syndrome.

Celebrating Bruce Mason
Directed by Shane Bosher
Performed by Stephen Lovatt

Thursday 20 November to Saturday 13 December
Preview Night: Wed 19 Nov – The End of the Golden Weather
Preview Night: Fri 21 Nov – Not Christmas, But Guy Fawkes
Sunday Special: Sunday 23 November – The End of the Golden Weather
Q&A: Tuesday 25 November
Choose Your Price Night: Wed 26 November – Not Christmas, But Guy Fawkes
Circa Two
Tues – Fri 7.30pm, Sat 4.30pm & 7.30pm, Sun 4.30pm
$30 – $60 Early Bird Tickets Available

Productions play on alternate nights with an opportunity to see both productions in conversation with each other on Saturdays

Gliding effortlessly between flights of poetic fancy and blunt everyday speech, THE END OF THE GOLDEN WEATHER is New Zealand storytelling at its very best.


NOT CHRISTMAS, BUT GUY FAWKES
An adolescent boy tries to find his place in an adult-dominated world. A young man retraces an intensely felt boyhood experience of bullying. A playwright in his last days reconciles the value of an artistic life and challenges the idea of New Zealand identity.

Comic disasters and confronting your own hubris. NOT CHRISTMAS, BUT GUY FAWKES is a richly autobiographical search for self-expression. Profound and true, it is a set of variations about over-reaching, cheekily confronting our very own Tall Poppy Syndrome.

Celebrating Bruce Mason
Directed by Shane Bosher
Performed by Stephen Lovatt

Please note The End of the Golden Weather and Not Christmas, but Guy Fawkes tickets need to be purchases separately, see the Circa Theatre website for full dates and ticket details.
events.description:
Bruce Mason is perhaps the most significant playwright in Aotearoa New Zealand’s theatrical history.
“I invite you to join me, in a voyage into the past, to that territory of the heart we call childhood.” Bruce Mason’s quintessential Kiwi classic chronicles the friendship between a 12-year-old boy and Firpo, a social outcast who dreams of winning an Olympic medal.
When the boy sets out to help Firpo make his athletic dream a reality, ignoring his father’s rebukes and community ridicule, a battle rages between the eternal optimism of childhood and the harsh pragmatism of adulthood.
A playwright in his last days reconciles the value of an artistic life and challenges the idea of New Zealand identity.
Celebrating Bruce Mason Directed by Shane Bosher Performed by Stephen Lovatt Please note The End of the Golden Weather and Not Christmas, but Guy Fawkes tickets need to be purchases separately, see the Circa Theatre website for full dates and ticket details.

events.id: Chit Chat with a Kit Kat-Johnsonville Library,34 Moorefield Road, Johnsonville, Wellington, New Zealand-All Events In
events.name: Chit Chat with a Kit Kat
events.venue: Johnsonville Library,34 Moorefield Road, Johnsonville, Wellington, New Zealand
events.long_description:
Chit Chat with a Kit Kat

Chit Chat with a Kit Kat and Coffee!

This is for 'all women' of all ages and from all walks of life who just need to be heard, and to share their worries, burdens, stresses, grief, sadness, loss etc.. and my friend and myself are realising there are alot of us out there experiencing these emotions for a myriad of reasons, be it loss, be it menopause, be it grief, stress, anxiety, depression, financial,family stuff, so my beautiful friend and I thought it would be a great idea to extend our little sessions that we have been having to more women who are in need of just being free to feel what we feel, to be honest, raw and open and not feel judged for our thoughts and emotions in a safe loving caring understanding space where we can support each other to be Brave Bold and Beautiful under pressure

We are human beings doing the best we can with what we have in a world that has sort of gone a bit pear shape hey, so this Beautiful Woman is about allowing you and me to speak our truth amongst like minded women in a safe space who are experiencing similar feelings and emotions with no judgement just love and understanding

The positive of this is when we vocalise and communicate our worries, concerns, hurts, disappointments, sadness, anger, frustrations, annoyances, we actually let go toxic energy from our mind, body, soul which actually improves our health and wellbeing mentally and physically, fact and truth!

Studies and Statistics have proven that 80% of illnesses are caused by STRESS, so let's just do something kind, caring, loving and healing for us and let's get together and get raw real and natural and chit chat about whatever it is you want to chit chat about, no judgement of course within reason lol :)

What do you think? Sounds fab? :)
If so then DM me or email to confirm, and i'll book you in on the 3rd of December or if you are just one of those bizzy Lizzy's like me and you forgot to book, then just feel free to rock up or text me which i will give you access to when you email

Where:
1.Johnsonville Public Library
2.Upstairs in a Private space
3.10am -12pm Just ask person at the desk where to go if you are unsure

p.s Great coffee shop next door on the same level :) or bring your own coffee or tea in a flask if that's what you prefer as I know some people are particular with their drinks :)

events.id: 5 Days Figure Sculpting Workshop With Model-Avalon Studios, 41 Percy Cameron Street, Avalon, Lower Hutt-Event Finder
events.name: 5 Days Figure Sculpting Workshop With Model
events.venue: Avalon Studios, 41 Percy Cameron Street, Avalon, Lower Hutt
events.long_description:
Working with a live model offers artists an invaluable opportunity to engage directly with the human form. The immediacy of the model’s presence encourages close observation and instinctive decision-making, leading to work that is expressive and real. This hands-on interaction brings a sense of movement and authenticity that’s hard to achieve otherwise.

The sculpting process typically starts by analyzing the model’s proportions and pose. A wire armature is built to support the structure, and clay is gradually applied to develop the form to a one-third life size, 750mm tall figure. From there, the artist refines the shapes focusing on anatomical accuracy and expressive detail that give the sculpture its final character.

Please visit the website to know more about the event.

With nearly 30 years of experience in traditional sculpture and the film industry, Javier is not just a sculptor — he’s a mentor. Trained in classical techniques, he studied fine arts and took anatomy courses at medical school, developing a rare combination of artistic and anatomical knowledge. He spent over five years at the world-renowned Weta Workshop, contributing to major films and exhibitions, and has worked across materials, scales, and digital technologies.

Material is included in the price.

Armature is supplied during the workshop.

You can buy our tools during the workshop if you like.

Tea, Coffee & snacks will be available.

We do share meals during the workshop.

Refunds are subjected to Terms & conditions

events.id: Self-Guided Tour of Stonehenge Aotearoa-Stonehenge Aotearoa, 51 Ahiaruhe Rd, Carterton-Event Finder
events.name: Self-Guided Tour of Stonehenge Aotearoa
events.venue: Stonehenge Aotearoa, 51 Ahiaruhe Rd, Carterton
events.long_description:
Explore Stonehenge Aotearoa at Your Own Pace

Our self-guided tour includes a map and a 12-minute audio-visual presentation to help you uncover the secrets of the henge. Afterward, head down to the stone circle and try out its unique acoustics — clap your hands and hear the echo respond, or whisper and see how far your voice carries.

A self-guided tour typically takes around 30 minutes, but many visitors stay longer simply because it’s so much fun. The bigger your group, the better the experience!

Please arrive at least 30 minutes before closing time.
Available during our opening hours: 10 AM – 4 PM.

events.id: Shared 90-Minute Guided Tour-Stonehenge Aotearoa, 51 Ahiaruhe Rd, Carterton-Event Finder
events.name: Shared 90-Minute Guided Tour
events.venue: Stonehenge Aotearoa, 51 Ahiaruhe Rd, Carterton
events.long_description:
Join a Shared Guided Tour and experience Stonehenge Aotearoa through the eyes of an expert. In this 90-minute journey, you’ll uncover how ancient cultures measured time, tracked the Sun and Moon, and connected the heavens with life on Earth.

Your experience begins with a captivating introduction and a 15-minute audio-visual presentation explaining how the Henge works. Then, step outside with your guide for a detailed tour of the stone circle, where astronomy, archaeology, and mythology come together in one unforgettable setting.

Perfect for visitors seeking a deeper understanding of the stars and stories that shaped human history.

events.venue: Johnsonville Uniting Church, 18 Dr Taylor Ter, Johnsonville, Wellington 6037, New Zealand
events.long_description:

In this class, we focus on core and pelvic floor reconnection, body balancing, and breath - creating a safe, solid foundation before returning to any other type of exercise.

events.id: Public History Talk: Writing Mr Ward’s Map-Corner Molesworth and Aitken Streets, Thorndon, Wellington-Facebook
events.name: Public History Talk: Writing Mr Ward’s Map
events.venue: Corner Molesworth and Aitken Streets, Thorndon, Wellington
events.long_description:
In the last Public History Talk for 2025, historian Elizabeth Cox will speak about her new book Mr Ward’s Map: Victorian Wellington Street by Street.
Wednesday 3 December 2025, 12:10pm to 1pm
Auditorium (Taiwhanga Kauhau), lower ground floor, National Library Building, corner Molesworth + Aitken Streets, Thorndon, Wellington and online.
A fascinating journey through Wellington’s past
In 1891, a remarkable map of Wellington was made by surveyor Thomas Ward. It recorded the footprint of every building, from Thorndon in the north, across the teeming, inner-city slums of Te Aro, to Berhampore in the south.
Updated regularly over the next 10 years, it detailed hotels, theatres, oyster saloons, brothels, shops, stables, Parliament, Māori kāinga, the Town Belt, the prisons, the ‘lunatic asylum’, and the hospital. The map is incredibly detailed — it even includes the location of street lights.
About the speaker
Elizabeth Cox is a Wellington historian who specialises in New Zealand’s social and architectural history. Her previous book, Making Space: A history of New Zealand women in architecture, was published in 2022.
These free Public History Talks are a collaboration between Te Puna Mātauranga o Aotearoa The National Library of New Zealand and Manatū Taonga Ministry for Culture and Heritage.
The talks are recorded and you can find them at the Apple store, Spotify and Podbean #newzealandhistory.
Register for a Zoom link: https://dia-nz.zoom.us/.../WN_lKZ5Kxg4TvSr8t8UffUNLA...

events.id: Amanda Bunting and Kris Zuelicke, Solos and Duets for Piano-St Andrews on the Terrace, 30 The Terrace, Wellington-Event Finder
events.name: Amanda Bunting and Kris Zuelicke, Solos and Duets for Piano
events.venue: St Andrews on the Terrace, 30 The Terrace, Wellington
events.long_description:
Leo Smit - Divertimento

Ginastera - Danzas Argentinas, Op. 2 - Danza del viejo boyero and Danza de la moza donosa

Ravel - Sonatine, M. 40, Modéré and Mouvement de Menuet

Schubert - "Lebensstürme," Allegro in A minor, D 947

Amanda Bunting, piano

Amanda Bunting is a graduate of the New Zealand School of Music, completing her Bachelor of Music with Honours in 2019 in solo piano performance with Dr. Jian Liu; small group ensemble with members of the NZSQ, and performance and embodiment studies with Dr. Hamish Robb and Dr. Margaret Medlyn. Prior to that, she completed a Graduate Diploma in Music in performance piano, performance studies, and pedagogy.

After previously studying with Gillian Bibby at the Conservatorium of Music and graduating in 1996, Amanda chose to return to study, with the guidance of Rosemary Bromley, to further develop performance skills and to gain further knowledge that can inspire and be shared with her piano students. Amanda is an Associate of the Institute of Registered Music Teachers New Zealand and a member of the Wellington Branch. She has an established private piano teaching studio, teaches piano at St Mark’s Church School, and also works as a Human Resources Adviser at Victoria University of Wellington.


Kris Zuelicke, piano

Kris Zuelicke grew up in a theatrical and musical family and began performing from age 5. During school years, she accompanied and sang in choirs and performed in community and Miami University Theatre productions, including on piano, cello and harpsichord. After earning undergraduate degrees in music, linguistics and German in the United States from Miami University and a master's in music theory with a cognate in music education from Indiana University, she taught music along with other subjects at Montessori schools in Bloomington, Indiana and in Landau, Germany. While living in Germany, Kris also enjoyed teaching at the Karlsruhe Teachers College, including developing courses that utilised the arts to teach English.

In New Zealand, Kris obtained a doctorate in harpsichord from the New Zealand School of Music, studying with Douglas Mews and Erin Helyard, and won scholarships to study with Mark Kroll in Boston. She currently teaches in schools around Wellington, while maintaining a private studio for piano and cello lessons, along with accompanying university exams at the NZSM. Kris enjoys playing chamber music with friends, and has performed with the Renaissance Singers, Manawatu Sinfonia, the Queen’s Closet and Stroma, along with a fun stint as a harpsichordist extra in the recently released Time Bandits.

events.id: Acoustic Routes December Social Club with Mary Livingston-1 Norman Ln, Johnsonville, Wellington 6037, New Zealand-Facebook
events.name: Acoustic Routes December Social Club with Mary Livingston
events.venue: 1 Norman Ln, Johnsonville, Wellington 6037, New Zealand
events.long_description:
Featuring guest Mary Livingston. Mary has been part of our local folk scene since she arrived in Wellington 50 years ago, with forays into classical guitar and various choirs. She has sung with many people...in the early days it was with Dave Nicholson & Mary Hubble. Later, she linked up with Sarah Duckworth & then Robin Brew, the Magpies (acapella 4 part), and Dr Livingston and the Presumptions (band with Don and Jill). Her current singing partner is Sue Chamberlain although Mary and Robin are dusting off their voci for an airing in early 2026! Mary loves to harmonise, and aims to not just come up with something that sounds nice, but that actually tries to enhance the sound of the singer with the tune, - a technique learned from her barbershop-Sweet Adeline sojourn. Today however we are going to hear Mary as a soloist. She will share a range of songs that she likes to sing on her own, and puts the harmony in with her guitar work. Some will be her own songs, and the rest is likely to focus on her take on some Celtic favourites using a DADGAD tuning on her guitar. Some of the songs will be familiar to you, but others less so. She is pretty excited about doing this, as it is rare for her to sing alone.
In the second half, we’ll go around the circle and you’re welcome to lead a song or tune if you wish.

events.id: Site Visit - BRANZ Fire Lab Tour-1222 Moonshine Road, Judgeford 5381, New Zealand-Humanitix
events.name: Site Visit - BRANZ Fire Lab Tour
events.venue: 1222 Moonshine Road, Judgeford 5381, New Zealand
events.long_description:
Join us for an exclusive NAWIC members-only site visit to BRANZ’s brand-new, world-leading Fire Laboratory—Aotearoa’s only facility capable of testing multi-storey buildings in realistic fire scenarios.
You’ll learn about BRANZ - who they are and what they do - and explore parts of a purpose-built 2,300 m² laboratory - including the fire lab, structure lab, and the materials lab.
The lab was officially unveiled in June this year, and will be fully operational by the end of 2025. It places New Zealand at the forefront of fire safety science, enabling full-scale fire testing previously unavailable in Australasia.
This is a rare opportunity to see where cutting-edge fire testing meets practical building safety solutions. Ideal for engineers, architects, building professionals, policymakers, or anyone interested in the science behind fire resilience.
Huge thanks to BRANZ for offering us this opportunity!
Event Details
Date: Wednesday, 3 December 2025
Time: 1:30 PM – 3:30 PM
Location: BRANZ Fire Laboratory, 1222 Moonshine Road, RD1, Porirua (parking available on site)
Capacity and Cost: FREE, with a maximum of 20 attendees (NAWIC Members Only)
PPE Requirements: Hi-vis vest, closed-toe shoes, and safety glasses

Join us for an exclusive behind-the-scenes tour of BRANZ’s brand-new Fire Laboratory in Porirua. Explore cutting-edge fire testing facilities and see how world-class research is shaping safer buildings.
 Please note: NAWIC is a voluntary organisation, committed to its obligations as a PCBU under the Health and Safety at Work Act 2015.   Amongst other things, this requires NAWIC to take all practicable steps to eliminate, isolate or minimize hazards that our event attendees are exposed to. Health and safety is a shared responsibility.

events.id: Randell Cottage writers-in-residence 2025 — Part of Randell Cottage writer-in-residence series-Cellar-Cafe, Molesworth St, Thorndon, Wellington 6011, New Zealand-Facebook
events.name: Randell Cottage writers-in-residence 2025 — Part of Randell Cottage writer-in-residence series
events.venue: Cellar-Cafe, Molesworth St, Thorndon, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
events.long_description:
Join author Saraid de Silva for an evening of conversation, readings, and video reflections from past Randell Cottage writers-in-residence, including Titaua Peu and Hinemoana Baker.
Join us at the Library or online. Register to receive a Zoom link: https://dia-nz.zoom.us/.../WN_p6_8lW8vSyOLAnFYTHhOgw...
A conversation with author Saraid de Silva
This year’s Randell Cottage writers-in-residence are Titaua Peu (French writer-in-resident) and Saraid de Silva (New Zealand writer-in-resident).
Join Saraid de Silva in conversation with Randell Cottage trustee Francis Cooke. Saraid will also read from her new novel, which promises to be very different from her first and acclaimed book Amma. But how different will it be from Amma’s stories that follow three generations of South Asian women? Saraid says her Untitled Second Novel is a revenge thriller about two best friends in a stolen car, crossing the country to crash a New Year’s Eve party.
Video reflections from former writers in residence
Following the conversation, French Cultural Counsellor, François Bockel, will present the latest in the series of short videos of writers-in-residence reflecting on their experience at Randell Cottage. Titaua Peu was the French writer-in-residence earlier this year, and New Zealander Hinemoana Baker was the 2024 New Zealand writer-in-residence.
The videos form part of Randell Cottage’s recorded oral history, designed to capture the essence of those writers and their interests while undertaking their fellowships.
RSVP to let us know you are coming
Light refreshments will be provided so RSVP before 1 December to info@randellcottage.co.nz.
Randell Cottage writer’s residency
Wellington’s historic Randell Cottage has been a writers’ residency for New Zealand and French writers since 2001. The Randell Cottage Writers Trust is supported by the New Zealand-France Friendship Fund/Arts Foundation of New Zealand, and the Wellington City Council. It works in close partnership with the Embassy of France.
About the speakers
Saraid de Silva is a Sri Lankan Pākehā writer and arts worker based in Tāmaki Makaurau. She was the co-creator and co-host of Radio New Zealand’s podcast and video series Conversations with My Immigrant Parents and has recently worked as a storyliner, script writer, and script editor on New Zealand television shows. Her first novel, Amma, was released in New Zealand and Australia by Hachette New Zealand in March 2024 and in the UK by Weatherglass Books in April 2024. It was long-listed for the Jann Medlicott Acorn Prize for Literature in the Ockham Awards and the UK Women’s Prize for Fiction.
Titaua Peu is a Tahitian novelist who stayed in Randell Cottage during the first half of 2025 as the French writer-in-residence. She is working on a new series of books that present a near future marked by a reverse migration, one in which inhabitants of Aotearoa have migrated north to the island of Mangareva in French Polynesia following a great war. The first laureate from French Polynesia, Titaua is considered one of the principal French-speaking voices in the literature of the Pacific, with her writings focusing on Polynesian society, the impact of colonialism and the place of women.

events.name: Are you my ancestor?
events.venue: 57 Willis St, Wellington Central, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
events.long_description:
Join us for Verb's final event of the year, where we mark International Day of Disabled People with literary flair – and a nod to the past. (FREE! But Registration appreciated at the link provided).
Crip the Lit writers will share an eclectic line-up of snappy new poems and prose celebrating the rich world of disability ancestors. Expect a few slyly subversive takes paired with deep, and often hilarious, insights.
Crip the Lit advocate for d/Deaf and disabled writers having their unique voices, perspectives and stories included and valued in mainstream writing. They are the talent behind some of our most popular LitCrawl events (most recently, 'I'm disabled ... of course I'm a villain!').
Featuring: Bee Trudgeon, Lucy Croft, Erin Donohue, Elizabeth Heritage, Mike Gourley, Wendi Wicks, Al Gray, Henrietta Bollinger, Lee Ota-Calderwood, Alice Mander, Robyn Hunt, Trish Harris, and Helen Vivienne Fletcher (MC).
Be part of this special occasion where we not only close out Verb's year, but also raise a toast to these exceptional artists.
This event is free to attend and includes tea & coffee. You can turn up on the day, or register to secure your spot. This event is NZSL interpreted.

events.id: Freedom and Responsibility in Science - WELLINGTON-11 Turnbull Street, Thorndon, Wellington 6011, New Zealand-Humanitix
events.name: Freedom and Responsibility in Science - WELLINGTON
events.venue: 11 Turnbull Street, Thorndon, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
events.long_description:
Join the Royal Society Te Apārangi for a wide-ranging panel discussion about the many threats to the integrity of science around the world, how they can be addressed, and New Zealand’s place in the global context. The panel will feature expert guest speakers from the International Science Council’s (ISC) Committee for Freedom and Responsibility in Science.
Science today faces many challenges: Scientific and academic freedoms are declining worldwide as anti-science ideology becomes imbedded in many of the world’s governments; state obligations towards enabling science as a human right remain chronically ignored; irresponsible scientific conduct and governance of all kinds increasingly undermine science from within; and the tally of wars and crises which rob the world of the scientific talent held by entire nations is growing year by year.
At precisely the moment when scientific progress on some of the existential threats to humanity is most urgent, science itself is under more pressure than perhaps ever before. So, what can we do?
About the ISC Committee for Freedom and Responsibility in Science:
The Committee monitors trends related to scientific and academic freedom globally, advises the ISC on official statements and positions, and advocates for the Principles of Freedom and Responsibility in Science. The Committee also engages in major projects at the intersection of science, human rights, and philosophy, such as the ISC’s recent interpretation of The Right to Participate in and Benefit from Science.
Event details:
5:40pm - Doors open
6:00pm - Panel discussion
7:15pm - Networking with drinks and canapés till 8:15pm

events.name: HUT KEEPERS
events.venue: 205 Ohiro Rd, Brooklyn, Wellington 6021, New Zealand
events.long_description:
DUE TO PUBLIC DEMAND
An extra screening on Wednesday, 3 December at 6:00 p.m.
A grassroots legacy for New Zealand's remote huts.
Amid decades of underfunding and bureaucratic gridlock, the future of New Zealand’s remote backcountry huts and tracks hangs in the balance. Frustrated by inaction, Andrew Buglass sets out to make a difference - hoping to spark a movement.
“We were hoping that it would become a movement, a shift in consciousness.” Hut Keepers is a story about doing what’s right - even when no one’s watching.
All ticket proceeds will go to the Backcountry Trust to fund work in the Tararua Forest Park.

events.id: Draw It Out - Fertility NZ national online workshop-Online - link provided on booking-Humanitix
events.name: Draw It Out - Fertility NZ national online workshop
events.venue: Online - link provided on booking
events.long_description:
A bespoke Draw It Out workshop for Fertility NZ, open to all genders.
Tickets: $34.50pp
Theme: Strengthen self-care for the holiday season
Strengthen your inner resources to care for yourself over the holiday season, and meet others going through similar experiences through this online national workshop, using a gentle powerful tool called Interactive Drawing Therapy.

FertilityNZ exists to support New Zealanders experiencing fertility problems, whether facing challenges becoming or staying pregnant. This bespoke workshop shares drawing for wellness, to tap into your inner guidance for support, within a safe space where others may be experiencing similar journeys.
Included in your workshop
You will be guided by Lara Phillips, a trained creative facilitator in Interactive Drawing Therapy, through drawing prompts (similar to a guided meditation or journaling) to draw out where you are at and draw out your own inner guidance. No art skills are needed, more simple mark making.
This gentle yet powerful tool uses drawing and writing as a way to access your subconscious and to listen to your heart rather than your head for guidance. A tool often used in therapy, it is made accessible for self-care and community wellness through these workshops.
What you will need
As this is an online workshop, you will need a computer in a comfortable, quiet setting. A hard surface to draw on (like a desk or a board), three to five pages of A3 paper (you can also tape two A4 printing papers together), and any colouring tools of your choice. Crayons are great as they are more child-like so you don't worry about how it looks. Coloured pastels or pencils are also good, or any coloured markers. The key is a range of colours.

About Lara Phillips
Lara Phillips is a creative facilitator trained in Interactive Drawing Therapy. With a 20 year career in creative copywriting in design and communication, she shares drawing and writing as a mode for wellness and self-care, to promote preventative and proactive mental health measures through creativity.
“We all have the wisdom within to help ourselves, if given the space.”
For more workshops or to book individual sessions visit www.drawitout.co.nz.
Liability disclaimer
Draw It Out offers creativity for wellbeing. It is not intended as therapy nor does it replace counselling, therapy, or any other medical or clinical professional help. Participants are guided to draw out where they are at, whilst drawing out their own inner resources for support and guidance.
Participants understand it is their own responsibility to manage their mental and physical health during sessions, to opt in and out of activities as they see fit, and make the facilitator aware if further support is required.

events.id: Harcourt Park spring league (Santioned)-49 Akatarawa Road, Porirua-Facebook
events.name: Harcourt Park spring league (Santioned)
events.venue: 49 Akatarawa Road, Porirua
events.long_description:
Spring League at Harcourt park is returning
Mark Wednesday the 29th October - 17 December 2025 on the calender, as this is the start of the next PDGA sanctioned league at Harcourt park, Upper Hutt brought to you by the Greater Wellington Disc Golf Club.
The league will be for 8 weeks til 5th and offer divisions by PDGA rating. If you don’t have a rating TD will assign you to a ratings group based on level of skill and experience.
Costs for the league is preferred to pay in advance or at first round and priorty will go to club members if the league reaches greater than 45 participants.
League Entry Fee:
$10 for Greater Wellington disc golf club members
$20 for Non club member (required to pay in advance of league or on first day of play).
$5 for casual play (required to pay on day of round).
League fees can be paid in cash on the night or direct into the club league account (preferred). Please use Spring25 & your last name as reference.
Kiwi Bank: 38-9016-0650973-03
Prizes - Divisional Winners will receive braging rights, two prizes will be provided to the 2 participants that shoot the most points above their rating in a single round (every one has a change at taking this one out)
Also there will be an optional extra jackpotting ace kitty. For the league. How to enter - gold coin entry each week. To be in the running for the week need to have paid in. Eg so week one pay $1 and in if hit an ace, week 2 not pay in therefore no entry into ace kitty, week 3 pay into ace kitty. Hit an ace week 2 can’t claim the kitty as did not pay in, hit an ace week 3 collect the ace kitty (shared if others also hit an ace that week).
You say what happens if no one hits an ace - keeps jackpotting throughout the clubs PDGA sanctioned leagues until an ACE is hit.
Current ACE Kitty sitting at $xxx

events.id: Miro Holland's 'Theo Thompson, welcome home' suite-Garibaldi Club, 118 Tory St, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand-Facebook
events.name: Miro Holland's 'Theo Thompson, welcome home' suite
events.venue: Garibaldi Club, 118 Tory St, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
events.long_description:
The Undercurrent presents... Miro Holland's 'Theo Thompson, welcome home' suite
Musicians:
Miro Holland - Trumpet
Theo Thompson - Guitar
Evie Patterson - Bass
Ateo Buhne - Drums
Isaac Randel - Saxophones
Top cats, and friends, invite you on a spiritual release. A new sound!
Welcome home Theo Thompson, back from the jazz clubs of Europe with us! After an acclaimed Jazz festival performance with his troupe minus one, Miro returns with an all original concept to the Undercurrent... Plus one!
This group have been playing together, in one form or another, for seven years- burgeoning out of the wallow and lulls of Wellington, the highs too- having shaped an entirely unique sound. Changing the rhythms and rhyme of the swing to whatever tendency is inherently antipodean.
Miro has written a new suite of music designed to amplify each of his friend's unique timbre, and make clear the joy of their collective sound. Be there!
Wednesday 3rd December
Doors 6:30pm/ Gig 7pm
$15
Tickets available online and on the door!
https://www.undertheradar.co.nz/.../Miro-Holland's-'Theo...

events.id: Sunset Guided Tour-Stonehenge Aotearoa, 51 Ahiaruhe Rd, Carterton-Event Finder
events.name: Sunset Guided Tour
events.venue: Stonehenge Aotearoa, 51 Ahiaruhe Rd, Carterton
events.long_description:
Experience Stonehenge Aotearoa at its most breathtaking — as the sun dips below the Wairarapa horizon.
Our Sunset Guided Tour blends astronomy, storytelling, and the natural beauty of twilight for an evening you will never forget.

Led by one of our knowledgeable guides, this 90-minute experience explores how ancient cultures used the Sun to track time and mark the turning of the seasons. You’ll discover the scientific and cultural thinking behind the Henge’s unique Southern Hemisphere design before watching the sunset alignment from inside the stone circle.

Weather permitting, you’ll witness how the setting Sun interacts with the structure — a striking moment that links ancient knowledge with the rhythms of the natural world.

Duration and Schedule
• Allow: Approximately 90 minutes
• Start Time: Begins one hour before sunset
• Availability: Offered any day with advance booking

events.name: Wellington - Information Lecture: A Path to a Healthy Body & Soul
events.venue: 7 Moncrieff Street, Mount Victoria, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
events.description:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BvGE7HCJEtw&t=4s Help and Healing on the Spiritual Path through the teaching of Bruno Groening - Medically Verifiable.
Bruno Groening (1906-1959) brought a simple message: there is a higher power that is the basis of all living things and it can heal.
He showed how this energy can be absorbed freely into the body, and through his teaching many people were cured back then as today, even from diseases that are considered incurable.
These success reports have been proven and documented within the Medical Scientific Group – a world-wide forum of independent medical doctors, psychologists and health care professionals within the Bruno Groening Circle of Friends.
Our Information Lecture is open to all interested people.

events.id: Not Christmas, but Guy Fawkes-Circa Theatre, 1 Taranaki St, Wellington-Event Finder
events.name: Not Christmas, but Guy Fawkes
events.venue: Circa Theatre, 1 Taranaki St, Wellington
events.long_description:
A theatrical double-shot from an iconic playwright and one of our greatest actors.

Bruce Mason is perhaps the most significant playwright in Aotearoa New Zealand’s theatrical history. Writing with courage and insight, he was a lover of language and a champion of the underdog.

Between 1959 and 1978, Bruce toured the country, telling uniquely Kiwi stories about emerging identity, cultural cringe and social difference. From church halls to country shearing sheds to the Edinburgh Festival, Bruce would play anywhere, in any circumstance, to any audience.

To celebrate his extraordinary legacy, Brilliant Adventures and Circa Theatre are collaborating to make two of his greatest solo works resound for a new age.

Two plays: timeless, universal, distinct. Following their critically acclaimed, sold out run of THINGS I KNOW TO BE TRUE, actor Stephen Lovatt and director Shane Bosher return to Circa for a not-to-be missed theatrical encounter with a master craftsman.


THE END OF THE GOLDEN WEATHER
“I invite you to join me, in a voyage into the past, to that territory of the heart we call childhood.”

Bruce Mason’s quintessential Kiwi classic chronicles the friendship between a 12-year-old boy and Firpo, a social outcast who dreams of winning an Olympic medal.

Through the boy’s eyes we see the wonder of life on a perfect beach, in a perfect 1930s New Zealand, during a perfect summer. It’s a world of magic and transformation, where anything can happen and miracles seem possible.

When the boy sets out to help Firpo make his athletic dream a reality, ignoring his father’s rebukes and community ridicule, a battle rages between the eternal optimism of childhood and the harsh pragmatism of adulthood.

Gliding effortlessly between flights of poetic fancy and blunt everyday speech, THE END OF THE GOLDEN WEATHER is New Zealand storytelling at its very best.


NOT CHRISTMAS, BUT GUY FAWKES
An adolescent boy tries to find his place in an adult-dominated world. A young man retraces an intensely felt boyhood experience of bullying. A playwright in his last days reconciles the value of an artistic life and challenges the idea of New Zealand identity.

Comic disasters and confronting your own hubris. NOT CHRISTMAS, BUT GUY FAWKES is a richly autobiographical search for self-expression. Profound and true, it is a set of variations about over-reaching, cheekily confronting our very own Tall Poppy Syndrome.

Celebrating Bruce Mason
Directed by Shane Bosher
Performed by Stephen Lovatt

Please note The End of the Golden Weather and Not Christmas, but Guy Fawkes tickets need to be purchases separately, see the Circa Theatre website for full dates and ticket details.

events.id: 5 days Figure Sculpting workshop with model-41 Percy Cameron Street-All Events In
events.name: 5 days Figure Sculpting workshop with model
events.venue: 41 Percy Cameron Street
events.long_description:
5 days Figure Sculpting workshop with model
The immediacy of the model’s presence encourages close observation and instinctive decision-making leading to work that is expressive and real. This hands-on interaction brings a sense of movement and authenticity that’s hard to achieve otherwise.

The sculpting process typically starts by analyzing the model’s proportions and pose. A wire armature is built to support the structure and clay is gradually applied to develop the form to a one-third life size 750mm tall figure. From there the artist refines the shapes focusing on anatomical accuracy and expressive detail that give the sculpture its final character.

With nearly 30 years of experience in traditional sculpture and the film industry Javier is not just a sculptor — he’s a mentor. Trained in classical techniques he studied fine arts and took anatomy courses at medical school developing a rare combination of artistic and anatomical knowledge. He spent over five years at the world-renowned Weta Workshop contributing to major films and exhibitions and has worked across materials scales and digital technologies.

Material is included in the price.
Armature is supplied during the workshop.
You can buy our tools during the workshop if you like.
Tea

Also check out other Workshops in Lower Hutt, Arts events in Lower Hutt, Fine Arts events in Lower Hutt.

events.id: How to Really Relax - Know your Mind - meditation class-Ashhurst Village Valley Centre,21 Guildford St, Ashhurst 4810, New Zealand, Ashhurst-All Events In
events.name: How to Really Relax - Know your Mind - meditation class
events.venue: Ashhurst Village Valley Centre,21 Guildford St, Ashhurst 4810, New Zealand, Ashhurst
events.long_description:
How to Really Relax - Know your Mind - meditation class
How to Really Relax - Know your Mind, meditation class
with Kadam Birgit Saunders

On the surface of a stormy ocean, there are waves and there can be a lot of turbulence.
But the deeper we go below the surface, the more still waters become regardless of the weather at the surface.
By looking within our own mind, we can find similar stillness and refuge from the stress and chaos of our modern life and learn to really relax.

We’ll set off on a gentle voyage of exploration of our mind, developing our understanding of the way in which our mind is the source of our awareness, how thoughts and feelings arise from but always dissolve back into our minds.
We will become more familiar with the deep and profound sense of clarity and peace that arises when our minds are still and undistracted, and which discover our inner potential for peace, happiness and real relaxation.

During this course we will learn and practise meditations that will help us to experience mental clarity and inner peace by meditating of our mind.
We will explore how meditating on our own mind offers us the ability to let go of stress and worry by enabling us to get a clearer, more dispassionate view of our own thoughts and feelings.

DETAILS
Our general programme classes include Dharma teachings along with guided meditations. Each class is self-contained and is also presented as part of a series. Drop into any class you like. These classes are suitable for both beginners and more advanced meditation practitioners. No special clothing is required. Most people sit on chairs. Everyone welcome!

events.id: Come Together — Kiwi vs Oz Rock Big End of Year Bash 2025-The Opera House, Wellington, New Zealand-Wellington NZ
events.name: Come Together — Kiwi vs Oz Rock Big End of Year Bash 2025
events.venue: The Opera House, Wellington, New Zealand
events.long_description:
For decades, New Zealand and Australia have sung along to each other’s songs. We’ve traded bands and tunes across the Tasman. The team of famous Kiwi musicians at Come Together are now putting it all to the test. Kiwi vs Oz Rock Big End of Year Bash 2025 packs the biggest hits from both sides of the ditch onto one stage. Some of New Zealand’s most iconic rock musicians will tear through these legendary antipodean tracks in an all-out rock fest. You can decide who truly owns rock. Is it the swagger of Aussie pub rock or the grit and heart of Kiwi anthems? Perhaps it’s both. 
Get ready to hear the biggest tunes from AC/DC, Split Enz, Cold Chisel, The Datsuns, INXS, DD Smash, Silverchair, Australian Crawl, and Hello Sailor. That’s just for starters, so the showdown is set to be epic. Here’s the kicker — you help shape the setlist, and when the amps power down, you vote for which nation takes home the crown. 
This is more than a concert — it’s a massive celebration of the music we grew up to, the songs that built us, and the riffs that still get us moving. Grab your mates, grab your tickets, and get ready to make some noise.

events.long_description:
Open Mic night @ G16 Upper Hutt
📣 Come along to a brand new open mic night at Garage 16 media in Upper Hutt.

Bring your originals, covers, instruments, voice, even your poems!

This is an opportunity to try something new, collaborate or refine what you’re already working on.

Grand piano, drums, keyboard, guitars and microphones are available to use.

Doors open from 5pm and Open mics begins at 6pm.

Bring yourself, friends and family, it will be warm and cosy inside 🔥

ABOUT G16
G16 (Garage Media 16) is Upper Hutt’s newest performing arts centre for musicians, creatives and artists. Aaron (owner) has opened this space for current and emerging artists to come along, perform, jam and connect.

Performance slots are 15 minutes long.
To book your slot visit the booking page here: https://dth.kiwi/dthopenmic.html

*Open mic slots are an open, friendly and supportive space to practice, experiments and gain experience and feedback through a fun and low pressure environment. These nights are for musicians of any age and ability 🎶

Terra Soma Yoga
You are welcomed to a gentle, invitational yoga experience.

Terra-soma yoga (translating to earth-body) weaves together hatha yoga, somatic inquiry, and nature connection, inviting you into awareness of your inner terrain. This approach encourages you to meet yourself as you are — to listen to the intelligence of your body's own rhythms and sense how they echo the wider rhythms of the earth. Through this listening, we enter a living, evolving conversation about well-being and what it can look like in today’s world.

How is your heart? We often hear “follow your heart” or “listen to your heart,” but what does that actually mean? In this class, you’ll be invited into heart somatic enquiry - locating this intelligent organ, listening into this space, and perhaps allowing it to lead, inform, or express through movement.

The structure of this hour-long class includes:

A gentle lead-in towards the heart

A mixture of supine, seated, and standing asana

Repeated sequences with encouragement to make them your own — add or subtract asana, move in your own time, with your own breath

Optional free movement explorations

This is an invitational practice — everything is a choice, not a must. Tailor the practice to suit yourself. Come as you are; everyone and all of you is welcome.

Your ticket includes a nourishing plant-based dinner and dessert, making this an evening of movement, heartful awareness, and wholesome connection.

Meet Abbie, your facilitator,
Abbie is a 200-hour certified yoga teacher who trained with Awakening Arts: School of Yoga and Eco Somatics. She deeply values the insight, liberation, inner and collective resources somatic movement practices can offer. Abbie has also completed a 50-hour training exploring how yoga can support trauma awareness, mental health, and body image. She thrives in and intends to create spaces where each person’s pace is honored and the body’s innate wisdom is encouraged to emerge and lead.

events.id: The Control Room by The Carpark Society-145 Victoria St, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand-Facebook
events.name: The Control Room by The Carpark Society
events.venue: 145 Victoria St, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
events.long_description:
The Control Room is the Phase Zero Rupture of The Car Park Society. It is a modest urban tenancy that functions as both public portal and member hub, seeding the Watcher Network and testing prototypes.
APOLOGIES THIS EVENT DOES NOT RUN ON THURSDAYS AS MENTIONED HERE...
The Car Park Society is about reclaiming forgotten or overlooked spaces, places where histories have been buried or distorted. The public are invited to interact with the four public activations in the central Te Aro location, uncovering these complex layers of our history. Join a stream of internal wānanga, using low-resource but high-impact methods - projection, sound, QR glyphs, symbolic ritual acts.
Activation 1 – 31 Oct: The First Rupture: The Exchange Projection overlays of colonial maps and glyphs. QR glyphs unlock File #1. “The burial is broken. You are observed.”
Activation 2 – 14 Nov: The Battle Archive: Manners St 1846 Projection overlays of “riot vs refusal.” Soundscape of haka, musket fire, colonial orders dissolving into static. QR glyphs unlock File #2. Oracle declares: “They called it riot. We call it refusal.”
Activation 3 – 28 Nov: The Drowned File: Reclaimed Land Projection of lost shoreline. Soundscape: waves + Harbour Board minutes. QR glyphs unlock File #3. “The sea still waits beneath. You are reclaimed.”
Activation 4 – 12 Dec: The Veins Beneath: Te Aro Pā / Waimapihi Projection of rippling water textures. Soundscape: awa + glitch static. QR glyphs unlock File #4. Oracle: “Ko te awa ahau. Ko te awa ko au. The memory flows.”

events.id: Thoughts That Make Us Think – Hugo Van Dorsser and Catarina Correia Arnhold-26 Constable St, Newtown, Wellington 6021, New Zealand-Facebook
events.name: Thoughts That Make Us Think – Hugo Van Dorsser and Catarina Correia Arnhold
events.venue: 26 Constable St, Newtown, Wellington 6021, New Zealand
events.long_description:
Twentysix is pleased to present the last show of the year by Ōtautahi based artist couple Hugo Van Dorsser and Catarina Correia Arnhold. With a sense of play and punchy, evocative colour at the centre - ‘Thoughts That Make Us Think’ is a meeting of material worlds. Gallery walls are met with a bold expression of life and an unapologetic exploration into how the artists’ materials can perform on behalf of their intuition and imagination. At times looking back in nostalgia, while others look inward toward the spirit and self.
Van Dorsser works, predominately in oil paint, in thick strokes. Drawn with a confident hand in building block shapes, he references childhood with toy cars and little houses, as well as employing the symbol of the butterfly to explore hope and change - all collaged together with a blurry face hidden at the side. They are dreamlike, the surreal spelt out with each canvas, Van Dorsser piecing together - and thus inviting his viewers - into an emotional landscape of shared nostalgia.
Correia Arnhold’s gritty clay shapes are a visualisation of emotion - created quickly, roughly - following her at the height of feeling. Spanning both three dimensional and wall bound, each piece is an exploration of the artist’s central symbols of the subconscious, religion and memory. Rough clay is layered in glossy, bright pastel glazes, set against deep, matte finishes - working in juxtaposition to expose conflicting narratives. Her use of the lone rider, priests, a crowd and holy figures throughout, asks of reality versus imagination, sentimentality versus fantasy, day to day versus the preternatural. An ongoing balance between a welcomed freedom of material and a language of myth, memory, and personal narrative.
The two artists sidestep together into a landscape of play. Testing boundary lines between material and reality, between fantasy and a blurred memory - all lit in vivid colour. ‘Thoughts That Make Us Think’ asks us to pace along after them, indulged in their two worlds.
Join us for the opening celebration on Friday, 28 November at 6pm – both artists will be present.
The exhibition runs from 29 November – 20 December 2025 at Twentysix Gallery.
Opening Hours:
Thursday 12pm - 6pm
Friday 12pm - 6pm
Saturday 10am - 4pm
Or by appointment

events.id: Westpac Smarts: Local innovation to global ambitions-Westpac Building,Level 10, Wellington, New Zealand-All Events In
events.name: Westpac Smarts: Local innovation to global ambitions
events.venue: Westpac Building,Level 10, Wellington, New Zealand
events.long_description:
Westpac Smarts: Local innovation to global ambitions
Westpac Smarts: Local innovation to global ambitions with the Village Goldsmith

About this Event

Join Westpac and the Wellington Chamber of Commerce for the final Westpac Smarts session of the year, featuring a local innovation story that is reshaping a global industry and offering real-world insights for local businesses with global ambitions.

Christine Douglas and Chris Benham from The Village Goldsmith will share the journey behind Floeting®, a world-first diamond setting technology developed in Wellington that’s a step away from traditional claws and clasps, allowing the diamond to appear to float.

Hear how this bold idea evolved into an inspiring story of global innovation, forged a landmark partnership with Tiffany & Co., and scaled to more than 50 countries - all while keeping design and IP anchored in Wellington.

Floeting® has captured the attention of the world’s luxury sector, with the Financial Times calling it “gravity defying” and Vogue France saying the diamond appears “freed from all metal, shining as if suspended above the jewel.” Their achievements have been recognised nationally, with Chris Benham named the winner of the EY Entrepreneur Of The Year™ 2025 New Zealand Product Category, alongside The Village Goldsmith receiving top honours at the NZ Hi-Tech Awards.

This is a relaxed, inspiring session for business leaders to sit back, connect, and reflect on how bold ideas backed by smart strategy can transform established industries.

Event details:
12:00pm - Networking
12:15pm – Presentation
1:15pm – Wrap-up

Chamber members and Westpac customers: Free entry
Non-members: $5.00 donated to Life Flight Trust through the Westpac Chopper Appeal
